Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of the I-Corps project is to optimize the efficiency of blood testing by minimizing costs, providing faster results, offering a more painless solution and increasing the convenience of where one?s blood is tested. A direct patient-to-lab interface allows for a new way of testing. This envisioned stand-alone testing kiosk could reach diabetes patients in remote, rural settings both domestically and internationally who have limited access to a healthcare facility. Our diagnostic testing solution could eliminate the need of a healthcare professional allowing blood collection and testing to be a very easy task to accomplish. Our product has the potential to incentivize more patients with blood-related diseases to get their blood tested, leading to quicker diagnosis and a better treatment plan.

This I-Corps project offers a blood collection device that utilizes a capillary extraction method, which has the potential to extract blood within seconds, rather than the standard venous draw, which takes longer and requires a healthcare professional. This method may be more painless than typical capillary extractions as the intended site of usage for lancet devices is the finger, which contains more sensitive pain receptors. In some instances we have received input that the constant pricking of a finger has become a nuisance which is why the site of action chosen has been the arm. The issue of vein accuracy is further a contributing factor to the blood collection device functionality as the issue is solved via the capillary method.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Kalmed kiosk was an all-in-one blood collection and analysis suite design for patients needing frequent blood monitoring.  The concept was akin the blood pressure kiosks that are found in most pharmacies. This concept was developed by two undergraduates: a biochemistry major and a biomedical engineering major.  They pitched the blood collection device to NSF and the team was admitted to the Portland OR. I-CORPS workshop held in January 2019.   The team recruited a faculty member at Georgia Tech to act as the PI and an industry mentor who accompanied to two undergrad ELs to the workshop.  The team was instructed to make contacts in advance of the workshop to interview while on site.  The Els were reminded that they were responsible for setting up relevant interviews in advance of the workshop. They had more than a month to do this.  When the team arrived, it became clear that no interviews had been arranged, so the team wandered in downtown Portland, randomly talking to people or looking for offices where blood collection for chronic diabetes might be occurring.  The team also visited the VA hospital, but no interviews had been arranged in advance. Throughout the week, the ELs demonstrated repeatedly a failure to follow directions. They were strongly reprimanded by the I-CORPS instructional team and warned that if NSF were not on furlong, they would have already been dismissed.  Even with this warning, their behavior did not change.  In consultation with the mentor and the instructional team, the PI decided that this team was not taking full advantage of the I-CORPS program and that they did not deserve to continue for the rest of the program. The remaining money was returned to NSF in early June.  

 


Last Modified: 07/01/2019
Modified by: Wendy Newstetter
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The Kalmed kiosk was an all-in-one blood collection and analysis suite design for patients needing frequent blood monitoring. The concept was akin the blood pressure kiosks that are found in most pharmacies. This concept was developed by two undergraduates: a biochemistry major and a biomedical engineering major. They pitched the blood collection device to NSF and the team was admitted to the Portland OR. I-CORPS workshop held in January 2019. The team recruited a faculty member at Georgia Tech to act as the PI and an industry mentor who accompanied to two undergrad ELs to the workshop. The team was instructed to make contacts in advance of the workshop to interview while on site. The Els were reminded that they were responsible for setting up relevant interviews in advance of the workshop. They had more than a month to do this. When the team arrived, it became clear that no interviews had been arranged, so the team wandered in downtown Portland, randomly talking to people or looking for offices where blood collection for chronic diabetes might be occurring. The team also visited the VA hospital, but no interviews had been arranged in advance. Throughout the week, the ELs demonstrated repeatedly a failure to follow directions. They were strongly reprimanded by the I-CORPS instructional team and warned that if NSF were not on furlong, they would have already been dismissed. Even with this warning, their behavior did not change. In consultation with the mentor and the instructional team, the PI decided that this team was not taking full advantage of the I-CORPS program and that they did not deserve to continue for the rest of the program. The remaining money was returned to NSF in early June. Last Modified: 07/01/2019 Submitted by: Wendy Newstetter
